paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT MEDICAL HISTORY: [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with hypertension admitted with acute renal failure secondary to hydralazine-induced glomerulonephritis. A request was made for conversion of a right internal jugular temporary pheresis catheter to a tunneled HD catheter.
CLINICIANS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1090**] [**Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 713**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 714**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 714**] is the attending radiologist who supervised the procedure.
ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine with epinephrine.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: A consent was obtained from patient's daughter after explaining the procedure and complications. Patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and sedated. Patient was placed supine on the angiography table and right side of neck as well as existing catheter prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout was performed. An initial scout radiograph demonstrated appropriate position of the existing line. After appropriate measurements were made, a subcutaneous tunnel was created from right anterior chest wall to the skin entry site of the existing catheter. A 14 French AngioDynamics catheter measuring 19 cm tip-to-cuff is pulled through the tunnel, exiting at site of the pre-existing catheter. Both ports of the original catheter were aspirated and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 379**] wire was advanced through one of the ports into the IVC. The existing line was then removed over the [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire and a peel-away sheath advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire and inner dilator were then removed. The double-lumen HD catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath and the sheath removed. Post-procedural chest x-ray demonstrated appropriate positioning of the dialysis catheter with tip positioned in the right atrium. Both ports aspirated and flushed easily. The skin incision over the venopuncture site closed with 4-0 Vicryl and the catheter anchored to the skin with 0-silk sutures. Sterile dressings were applied.
The patient tolerated the procedure well without any immediate complications.

The left atrial AP dimension was mildly increased. The left atrial dimensions in the 4-chamber view was mildly increased. The left ventricular end-diastolic dimension was mildly enlarged. The left ventricular end-diastolic volume index was moderately elevated. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction was severely depressed at 29%, with severe regional and global systolic function. There was severe global hypokinesis/akinesis with relative sparing of the basal and mid portions of the inferior and inferolateral walls. The left ventricular mass was normal. The right ventricular end-diastolic volume index was normal. The calculated right ventricular ejection fraction was normal at 51%, with normal regional and global systolic function. The aortic valve was trileaflet with normal valve area.
Quantitative Flow There was no significant intra-cardiac shunt. Aortic flow demonstrated no significant aortic regurgitation. There was no significant mitral regurgitation. The right ventricular stroke volume and pulmonic flow demonstrated mild pulmonic and tricuspid regurgitation.
Viability There was hyperenhancement of the basal anterior septum, the mid and distal portions of the inferoseptal, anteroseptal, anterior, and anterolateral segments, and the apex. The hyperenhancement was transmural, consistent with poor (<20%) likelihood of functional recovery after segment revascularization. The infarct/LV mass ratio was 0.33.

FINAL REPORT Please note that this is a redictation. The previous dictation has been lost during the process of transcription.
CLINICAL HISTORY: 86-year-old male with a subarachnoid hemorrhage along the Sylvian fissures bilaterally and small intraventricular hemorrhage in the occipital horns bilaterally.
TECHNIQUE: Informed consent was obtained from the patient and the patient's family after explaining the risks, indications and alternative management. Risks explained included stroke, loss of vision and speech, temporary or permanent, with possible treatment with stent and coils if needed.
The patient was brought to the Interventional Neuroradiology Theater and placed on the biplane table in supine position. Both groins were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Access to the right common femoral artery was obtained using a 19-gauge single wall needle, under local anesthesia using 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium bicarbonate and with aseptic precautions. Through the needle, a 0.35 [**Last Name (un) 52**] wire was introduced and the needle taken out. Over the wire, a 5 Fr vascular sheath was placed and connected to a saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of saline) with a continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 Fr Berenstein catheter was introduced and connected to continuous saline infusion (with mixture of 1000 units of heparin in 1000 cc of saline).
The following blood vessels were selectively catherized, and arteriograms were performed from these locations: left common carotid artery, left internal carotid artery, left subclavian artery, left vertebral artery.
LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: No significant atherosclerotic disease noted.
LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: There is good opacification of the left proximal and distal left internal carotid artery, anterior and middle cerebral artery branches. There is a small aneurysm measuring approximately 2.5 mm in diameter with a wide neck and appears to arise at the origin of the posterior communicating artery.
LEFT VERTBRAL ARTERY: There is minimal narrowing noted at the origin of the left vertebral artery. There is good opacification of the proximal and distal left vertebral artery, basilar artery and posterior cerebral arteries on both sides.
The right internal carotid artery and the right vertebral artery could not be catheterized secondary to severe tortuosity of the vessels and the patient's breathing. The patient will be brought back for re-angiogram of these vessels under general anesthesia.

FINAL REPORT CLINICAL INDICATION: 75 year old male with intracranial hemorrhage after a fall and findings on a prior noncontrast CT scan concerning for an aneurysm or mass.
TECHNIQUE: Axial imaging of the brain without IV contrast enhancement, followed by helical CT imaging of the major intracranial arteries during rapid infusion of 100 cc of Optiray. Subsequent delayed contrast enhanced images of the brain were obtained.
CT BRAIN W/O IV CONTRAST: The patient's known bilateral mixed density subdural collections are again noted. These appear unchanged in size and extent in the interval. There is persistent flattening of the adjacent cerebral gyri as well as narrowing of the lateral ventricles. The basal cisterns are not effaced. The [**Doctor Last Name 181**]-white matter differentiation is preserved. The previously described 15 x 8 mm hyperdense focus along the left anterior clinoid and the suprasellar space appears unchannged. There are probable punctate calcifications within it. Differential considerations include aneurysm or dense mass.
CTA OF INTRACRANIAL CIRCULATION: The above described hyperdense focus adjacent to the left anterior clinoid and suprasellar space does not demonstrate any evidence of enhancement during the arterial bolus. Additionally, there is rightward displacement of the supraclinoid portion of the left internal carotid artery as well as posterior displacement of the M1 segment of the left MCA, indicating an element of mass effect. However, both of these vessels appear to be intact. There is no evidence of aneurysmal dilatation. The visualized intracranial arterial circulation is otherwise normal.
DELAYED CONTRAST ENHANCED CT IMAGES OF THE BRAIN: The previously described hyperdensity corresponds to a lobular mass abutting the left anterior clinoid and adjacent suprasellar space. This lesion demonstrates modest contrast enhancement and contains punctate calcifications within it. The most likely differential consideration in this location given these characteristics is a meningioma.

FINAL REPORT FNA OF THE CERVICAL LYMPH NODES
INDICATION: 73-year-old man with right-sided cervical lymphadenopathy concerning for malignancy.
After risk, benefits, alternatives and procedure were explained to the patient, written informed consent was obtained. A preprocedure timeout was performed using three patient identifiers.
Initial ultrasound imaging showed three lymph nodes in the right side of neck, measuring up to 1.8 x 2 cm. The middle of these was chosen for FNA due to size and relative distance from adjacent jugular and carotid vessels.
The site in the right neck was marked, then prepped with alcohol.
25-gauge needle was used to perform two passes of the FNA through the lymph nodes under direct ultrasound guidance (the first with suction and second without suction). The material from the first pass was evaluated by on-site cytology team and was deemed adequate. The second sample was sent in cytolyte, as advised by cytology.
The patient tolerated the procedure well. No immediate post-procedure complications were noted.
The attending radiologist, Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2916**] [**Name (STitle) 2917**] was present and supervised the whole procedure.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 83-year-old male with left pontine infarction with dense right hemiplegia. Long-term feeding required.
RADIOLOGISTS: Drs. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 737**] [**Doctor Last Name **] [**Doctor Last Name 325**], and [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2091**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 27**]. Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name5 (PTitle) 325**] and [**Doctor Last Name 27**] were present throughout procedure.
CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS: 20 ml of Optiray 320 at 60%. 100 mcg of Fentanyl and 1 mg Versed were given intravenously in divided doses under continued hemodynamic monitoring for conscious sedation.
PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS: The procedure was described and informed consent obtained. The stomach was insufflated with air, and point of entry into the body of stomach was marked. Following local anesthetic infiltration, a 19 gauge spinal needle was inserted under fluoroscopic guidance until tenting of the stomach wall was noticed. The lumen of the stomach was then entered, and a flush of air was noted through the spinal needle. At this time, a 0.035 Bentson guidewire was placed through the needle into the lumen of the stomach, and the needle was removed. The tract was then dilated using 6, 8, 10, 12, and 14 French dilators under fluoroscopic guidance. A small amount of contrast material was injected during the course of dilatation which again demonstrated gastric location. The tract was continually dilated up to 18 French, and a 16 French MIC gastrostomy tube was advanced over a stiff guidewire. At this time, contrast was injected through the tube and demonstrated its tip to be still in the stomach. A significant amount of previously injected contrast material was noted in a large hiatal hernia projecting above the left hemidiaphragm. With the guidewire projecting over the body and fundus of the stomach, the securing balloon of the MIC gastrostomy tube was inflated with contrast material and normal saline, and was noticed to project outside the body of the stomach. The tube was deflated, the wire removed, and contrast material was then injected directly through the gastrostomy tube, which demonstrated a peritoneal location.
The stomach was reinsufflated with air, and two T-fasteners were placed through the wall of the stomach and secured to the anterior abdominal wall. A 19 gauge needle was then used to access the stomach in an adjacent separate puncture site over the anterior abdominal wall. An 0.035 wire was placed through the needle, the needle removed, the tract dilated to 7 French. A 7 French sheath was then placed over the needle, and access into the gastric antrum was obtained. A 5 French multipurpose catheter was advanced over the guidewire, and the guidewire was exchanged for an angled glidewire. Following several technical manipulations, the guidewire was passed through the first portion of the duodenum and eventually beyond the ligament of Treitz. The multipurpose catheter was advanced over the guidewire, and the glidewire was exchanged for an Amplatz Superstiff guidewire. The multipurpose catheter and 7-French sheath were removed, and a 14 French dilator/peelaway sheath was then advanced over the Superstiff guidewire into the duodenum. The inner dilator was removed, and a 14 French [**Doctor Last Name 2583**] gastrojejunstomy catheter was placed through the peelaway sheath. With continued advancement of the catheter through the proximal duodenum, the guidewire in the ligament of Treitz retracted. This in part was due to the lack of flexibility in the gastroduodenal region, secondary to the presence of a large hiatal hernia. At this time, a T-fastener placed previously was noted to have dislodged during advancement of the catheter and peelaway sheath. At this time, four new T- fasteners were placed under fluoroscopic guidance under continued gas insufflation via the NG tube. Access was again gained to the body of the stomach, and a 14 French pigtail catheter was placed fluoroscopic guidance, such that the pigtail formed in the antrum of the stomach. The catheter was secured to the patient's skin using 0 Prolene suture material and Flexitrak dressing.
COMPLICATIONS: Free air was noted under the hemidiaphragms during and following the procedure. The possibility of gastric versus duodenal perforation was a concern, and a CT scan of the abdomen was arranged for the following day.

answers.text: Free air was noted under the hemidiaphragms

FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 84-year-old man with emphysema, atrial fibrillation and urosepsis. Requesting placement of PICC for antibiotics.
OPERATORS: Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 501**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 411**] [**Doctor Last Name 412**].
PROCEDURES: 1. Post-pyloric tube placement. 2. PICC line placement.
POST-PYLORIC TUBE PLACEMENT: The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine upon the table. A scout view of the neck and chest demonstrates a Dobbhoff tube terminating in the stomach. An initial attempt was made to place a wire through the Dobbhoff tube, however, given its thickness, it could not be exchanged for separate catheters. As such, the Dobbhoff two and wire were removed and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1213**]-[**Doctor First Name 948**] feeding tube was placed via the left naris with internal wire which were easily extended down beyond the pylorus, with the tip terminating just prior to the ligament of Treitz. The wire was removed and contrast injected, confirming this location. A final fluoroscopic view of the abdomen was obtained. There were no immediate complications.
PICC LINE PLACEMENT: The patient's right arm was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout and huddle were performed per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.
TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set. Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a guidewire and a double lumen PICC line measuring 39 cm in length was then placed through the peel-away sheath with its terminating in the cavoatrial junction. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.
The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.

FINAL REPORT HISTORY: Inferior ST elevation MI complicated by ATN and acute renal failure. The patient has been on CVVH then temporary hemodialysis with need for more permanent access. Request for conversion of the temporary line to a tunneled line.
Comparison is made to prior examination of [**2154-3-18**].
OPERATORS: The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 255**], Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 17**], and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**], the attending radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.
PROCEDURE: Successful conversion of prior temporary dialysis line to left- sided 15.5 French 23 cm cuff-to-tip dual-lumen dialysis catheter.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: Informed consent was obtained from the patient and the [**Hospital 353**] healthcare proxy via telephone. A preprocedure timeout was performed documenting the nature of procedure and the patient identity. The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the indwelling left neck/left dialysis catheter was prepped and draped in normal sterile fashion. Initial scout radiograph demonstrated appropriate positioning of the line. First, attention was made towards creation of a tract. Appropriate measurements were made and the subcutaneous tissues were anesthetized with epinephrine buffered lidocaine. A small incision was made and the dialysis catheter was tunneled through the left chest wall subcutaneous tissue. The indwelling catheter was then aspirated removing all heparin and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 66**] wire was advanced through the indwelling lumen into the IVC. The previously placed line was then removed over a wire and a 16 French sheath/dilator device was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the SVC. The indwelling [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire and dilator device were then removed and the dual-lumen dialysis catheter was advanced through the peel-away sheath. Post-procedural radiograph demonstrated appropriate positioning of the dialysis catheter with the tip in the right atrium. The skin [**Doctor Last Name 695**] near the jugular access entry point was closed with 2-0 Vicryl and the catheter was secured with 0 silk. Sterile dressings were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate post-procedure complications.
Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of 50 mcg of fentanyl throughout the total intraservice time of 45 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.

FINAL REPORT HISTORY: 44-year-old male status post short-segment ileal resection following blunt abdominal trauma, now with diarrhea and GI bleeding. CT scan suggested focal Crohn's disease at the anastomotic site. Evaluate for extent of small bowel inflammation or other pathology.
COMPARISON: CT of the abdomen and pelvis dated [**2155-9-15**].
TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted imaging was performed on a 1.5 Tesla magnet, including dynamic 3D imaging performed prior to, during, and following the uneventful intravenous administration of 0.1 mmol/kg (17 ml) of Magnevist intravenous contrast. VoLumen oral contrast and 1 mg of intramuscular glucagon was also administered.
Multiplanar 2D and 3D reformations and subtraction images were generated and evaluated on the workstation.
FINDINGS: Anteriorly in the mid-abdomen, at site of prior ileal resection and end- to- end anastomosis, there is a short-segment of slightly abnormal small bowel. This demonstrates transient saccular dilitation just upstream of the anastomotic site, but normal peristalsis on functional imaging. There is equivocal wall thickening and a small focus of equivocal hyperenhancement (200:68). However, there is no significant adjacent mesenteric inflammation or edema.
Of note, the mesentery adjacent to this site does appear somewhat distorted, with overall deviation to the right abdomen. Given the mesenteric distortion, the possibility of an internal hernia cannot be entirely excluded.
The remainder of the small bowel is unremarkable. The large bowel is normal in appearance without wall thickening or distention. There is no fluid collection to suggest abscess formation. Small scattered mesenteric nodes are not pathologically enlarged.
The visualized liver is normal in appearance. There is no biliary ductal dilatation. The spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, and pancreas are normal. The major mesenteric vessels are widely patent. The bladder is normal in appearance. The visualized marrow signal is normal.
Multiplanar reformations provided multiple imaging perspectives for the dynamic series.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT MEDICAL HISTORY: 70-year-old man with thyroid and esophageal cancer needing chemotherapy. The patient is known to have difficult venous access and IV team could only place a midline catheter as the wire could not be advanced centrally. As the patient needs central access for chemotherapy, a request was placed for IR-guided exchange or placement of a new PICC line with tip positioned centrally.
CLINICIANS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 9422**] [**Name (STitle) 90**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, reviewed the study.
ANESHTESIA: Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the procedure and risks involved to the patient. The left upper arm including the existing midline catheter was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.
Initial scout image of the left upper arm was obtained demonstrating a midline catheter with tip terminating just distal to the axilla. Attempts to either aspirate blood or to flush through either port of the catheter were unsuccessful. A 0.018 guidewire was placed through one of the ports, but the wire could not be advanced past the level of the axilla. At this stage, a small amount of contrast was injected through one of the ports demonstrating the catheter to be extravascular. Therefore, the catheter was removed. A new access was obtained into a left brachial vein with a micropuncture set and ultrasound images were stored before and after gaining intravenous access. A 0.018 guidewire was placed through the micropuncture sheath, but again the wire could not be advanced past the level of axilla. Therefore, a small amount of contrast was injected demonstrating patent but tortuous veins at the level of axilla. A 0.035 Glidewire was placed through the micropuncture sheath and advanced easily past this level into SVC. A 5 French Kumpe catheter was placed over the Glidewire and the wire exchanged for a 0.018 PICC line wire. The Kumpe catheter was removed and a peel-away sheath was placed over the guidewire and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line measuring 55 cm in length was placed through the peel-away sheath with the tip positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. A fluoroscopic spot chest film was obtained and stored digitally. The catheter was secured to skin with a Stat-Lock device and sterile dressings were applied. Both ports of the catheter were easily aspirated and flushed. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 83 year old male status post pontine infarction. A gastrostomy tube was placed percutaneously approximately one month ago. Please replace by a gastrojejunostomy tube for aspiration prophyllaxis.
RADIOLOGISTS: Drs. [**First Name (STitle) 737**] [**Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (LF) 325**], [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 2742**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 4496**], and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) 325**], Staff Radiologist, was present throughout the procedure.
CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS: 20 ml of Optiray 320 at 60%, in stomach and [**Last Name (un) **]. IV conscious sedation with divided doses (total 1 mg) of Versed intravenously under continuous hemodynamic monitoring.
PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS: The procedure was described to the patient's next of [**Doctor First Name **] and informed consent obtained. The previously-placed 14-French pigtail catheter, with the tip in the gastric antrum, was removed over a 0.035 Super Stiff Amplatz wire, and a 5-French sheath was then passed over the wire such that its distal tip was in the antrum of the stomach. A 5-French multi- side-hole catheter was then advanced over the wire, and the wire was exchanged for a 0.035 angled Glidewire. With the image intensifier in a steep left anterior oblique plane, several attempts were made to pass through the post- pyloric region using the Glidewire and with the aid of the catheter, but were unsuccessful. The catheter was then exchanged for a 5-French [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] II catheter, again unsuccessfully. A 5-French [**Location (un) 4398**] catheter was then used in conjunction with the angled Glidewire, and were both manipulated well into the jejunum beyond the ligament of Treitz. The wire was then removed, and replaced with the 0.035 Amplatz Super Stiff wire. Both the catheter and 5-French sheath were then removed, and a 14-French peel-away sheath was advanced over the Amplatz Super Stiff wire into the post-pyloric region. A 14-French [**Doctor Last Name 2583**] gastrojejunostomy catheter was then placed through the peel-away sheath following removal of the inner dilator. The sheath was simultaneously removed. The pigtail mechanism was then formed in the third portion of the duodenum, and the tip placed well into the jejunum. A gastrojejunostogram was then performed, and radiographic images were obtained. The final images demonstrate the locking loop mechanism to be projecting over the third portion of the duodenum, with the tip of the catheter well into the jejunum beyond the ligament of Treitz. There is contrast material visualized in the body of the stomach and no extravasation. The catheter was then sutured to the patient's skin using 0 Prolene suture material. A Flexi-Track dressing was applied, and sterile gauze applied over the entry site.
COMPLICATIONS: None.

FINAL REPORT INDICATION: Status post MVA with CT showing mediastinal hematoma. Aortogram was requested by Trauma Service.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The risks and benefits were explained to the patient's family and consent was obtained.
The attending Radiologist, Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 134**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 135**], was present during the entire procedure.
The patient was placed supine on the angiographic table and the right groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Under 1% Lidocaine local anesthesia, the right common femoral artery was accessed with a 19-gauge needle and a .035 [**Last Name (un) 414**] wire was advanced into the abdominal aorta through the needle. The needle was exchanged for a 7 French [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Doctor Last Name 4740**] catheter, which was advanced over the wire into the ascending aorta with the tip just above the aortic valve. An aortogram was performed in RPO and LPO projections respectively with injection of nonionic contrast. The aortogram demonstrated a normal appearing ascending aorta, aortic arch and descending aorta, all major branches from the arch, as well as bilateral internal mammary arteries. The left common carotid artery has a common origin with brachiocephalic artery. There is no evidence of contrast extravasation, irregularity or aneurysm. The tip of the left chest tube is abutting the aortic arch. This finding was relayed to the ICU resident. At the end of the procedure, the catheter was removed over the wire and hemostasis was achieved with manual compression.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 70-year-old man with anaplastic thyroid cancer and esophageal cancer with dysphagia requiring G-tube placement.
PHYSICIANS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7210**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 557**] attending radiologist.
PROCEDURE: 1. Initial spot fluoroscopic image. 2. Removal of existing malpositioned nasogastric tube. 3. Placement of a 5 French catheter into the stomach. 4. Placement of a 12 French percutaneous Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 7943**] gastrostomy tube and 3 T-tacks. 5. Post-tube placement spot fluoroscopic imaging with contrast injection.
MEDICATIONS: Moderate sedation was provided with divided doses of 0.5 mg IV Versed and 25 mcg IV fentanyl throughout the intraprocedure time, during which continuous hemodynamic monitoring was performed. Additionally, the patient received 1 g IV Kefzol prior to the procedure.
PROCEDURE: Prior to initiation of the procedure, written informed consent was obtained and a preprocedure timeout was performed. Upon initiation of procedure, the patient had excessive coughing and bloody sputum. Initial fluoroscopic spot image was performed demonstrating the nasogastric tube malpositioned within the retropharynx. The nasogastric tube was removed and under fluoroscopic guidance, a 5 French glide catheter and guidewire were used to position the catheter within the stomach. This was secured to the nose. Next, the abdomen was prepped and draped in sterile manner. The stomach was insufflated with air. Under fluoroscopic guidance, after local lidocaine administration, a needle was advanced into the stomach, and a T-Tack was deployed. Location was confirmed with contrast injection. Sequentially, two additional T-tacks were deployed. Following this, an 18-gauge needle was used to access the stomach, for which an 0.035 J-wire was advanced. Sequential fascial dilatation was performed followed by placement of a 12-French Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 7943**] tube. The pigtail was formed within the stomach. Contrast injection confirmed location. The T-tacks were secured to the skin with 0 silk suture. A dressing was applied. The patiet tolerated the procedure well and left the IR suite in good condition.

FINAL REPORT INDICATION: Elderly woman with altered mental status and atrial pacer wire abscess. Status post fall with patellar fracture shown on previous x-ray. Follow-up examination.
FINDINGS:
AP view of the right knee with the patient in supine position demonstrates normal alignment without evidence of fracture or dislocation. Joint distances are preserved in both medial and lateral compartments. Very small osteophytic reactions are noted at the medial edge of the tibial plateau, but no other significant degenerative abnormalities are identified.
The lateral view confirms the preserved integrity of the knee joint and displays the patella in normal position. No evidence of joint effusion. Rather extensive arterial wall calcifications are seen in the distal superficial femoral artery and popliteal artery and secondary divisions.
AP view of the left knee also demonstrates normal alignment of the skeltal structures within the knee joint with preserved knee joint distances in both medial and lateral compartments. No significant degenerative manifestations are identified. Lateral view confirms preserved integrity of distal femur and proximal tibia and fibula, but the patella demonstrates structural abnormalities characterized by a semi-translucent line with some locally increased sclerosis consistent with a transverse nondisplaced fracture, apparently now healed. Again analysis of soft tissue structures does not disclose evidence for joint effusion. Also on the left side the patient has extensive arterial wall calcifications.
There exists no previous similar study in our records available for comparison.

FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 85-year-old woman with facial surgery unable to take oral intake. Placement of percutaneous gastrostomy tube.
COMPARISON: none.
CLINICIANS: Dr. [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 1580**] [**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1581**] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 753**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 754**]. Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 753**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 754**], the attending radiologist, was present and supervising throughout.
ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of a total of 50 mcg of fentanyl, while patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored. Local anesthesia was provided with 1% buffered lidocaine.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:
An informed written consent was obtained after explaining the procedure, benefits, alternatives and risks involved. The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table. The upper abdomen was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure huddle and timeout was performed as per [**Hospital1 51**] protocol.
A scout image of the abdomen was obtained and stored. The stomach was insufflated with air through the indwelling nasogastric tube. Under fluoroscopy, the outline of the stomach and colon were noted. The liver edge was was identified by percussion. Then under fluoroscopic guidance, three T-fastener buttons were sequentially deployed elevating the stomach to the anterior abdominal wall in a triangular fashion. A small skin incision was made between the T-fastener buttons and an 18-gauge needle was introduced into the stomach under fluoroscopic guidance. The position of the needle was confirmed with small amount of contrast injection. The needle was removed over [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 539**] wire and soft tissue tract dilated. Then a 12 French Wills-[**Doctor Last Name 5929**] G-tube was placed over the wire. Guidewire was removed and retaining loop of the catheter was formed in the stomach and locked after confirming the position of the catheter by contrast injection. FINAL REPORT CLINICAL HISTORY: History of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The patient had a previous angiogram on the previous day. The patient was moving and it was difficult to catheterize the right internal and right vertebral arteries at the time. Hence the patient was brought back and the present angiogram was performed under general anesthesia.
TECHNIQUE: Informed consent was obtained from the patient and the patient's family after explaining the risks, indications and alternative management. Risks explained included stroke, loss of vision and speech, temporary or permanent, with possible treatment with stent and coils if needed.
The patient was brought to the Interventional Neuroradiology Theater and placed on the biplane table in supine position. Both groins were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Access to the right common femoral artery was obtained using a 19-gauge single wall needle, under local anesthesia using 1% lidocaine mixed with sodium bicarbonate and with aseptic precautions. Through the needle, a 0.35 [**Last Name (un) 52**] wire was introduced and the needle taken out. Over the wire, a 5 Fr vascular sheath was placed and connected to a saline infusion (mixed with heparin 500 units in 500 cc of saline) with a continuous drip. Through the sheath, a 4 Fr Berenstein catheter was introduced and connected to continuous saline infusion (with mixture of 1000 units of heparin in 1000 cc of saline).
The following blood vessels were selectively catherized, and arteriograms were performed from these locations: right common carotid artery, right internal carotid artery, right vertebral artery.
Please note that the previous dicatation has been lost in the process of transcription. This is a redictation.
RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: No significant atherosclerotic disease noted.
RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: There is good opacification of the proximal and distal right internal carotid artery, anterior and middle cerebral artery branches. There is an irregular aneurysm noted arising from the posterior communicating artery and measures approximately 10 x 6 x 4 mm in size. This appears to be the source of the hemorrhage.
RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: There is good opacification of the proximal and distal right vertebral artery, basilar artery and posterior cerebral artery on both sides. No definite aneurysm noted.

paragraphs.context:
INDICATION: 30-year-old female pregnant with TTP-HUS and severe preeclampsia with low platelet count. Requiring urgent plasmapheresis.
OPERATORS: Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 501**] (fellow) and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 731**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 63**] (attending).
ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of fentanyl (25 cmcg) over the total intra-service time of 20 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.
PROCEDURE: After risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient, written informed consent was obtained. The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the table. The right neck was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. A pre-procedure timeout and huddle were performed per standard [**Hospital1 184**] protocol. The patient was placed in left semi-lateral decubitus position (LPO-[**Doctor Last Name 14451**]).
Under son[**Name (NI) 536**] guidance with hard copy images on file, the right internal jugular vein was cannulated with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle through which a 0.018 wire was advanced into the superior vena cava. The needle was exchanged for a micropuncture sheath. The inner dilator and wire were removed and a short [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava. Over the wire, sequential dilation was performed up to 14 French and the triple-lumen hemodialysis catheter (including VIP port) was advanced over the wire with tip terminating in the right atrium. The wire was removed and the catheter aspirated and flushed easily. A final fluoroscopic image of the chest was obtained from this location. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 0 silk suture and capped and dressed appropriately. There were no immediate complications.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 83 year-old male with recent diagnosis of breast cancer, congestive cardiac failure and possible pneumonia. Also had recent right heart catheterization. Request to evaluate pleural effusions and to rule out retroperitoneal bleed following cardiac catheter study.
COMPARISON: Reference is made to a previous renal ultrasound of [**9-4**] and abdominal ultrasound of [**5-12**].
TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT-acquired axial images were obtained from the lung apices to the level of the lesser trochanters. No intravenous contrast was administered due to the patient's impaired renal function. Coronal and sagittal reformats were evaluated.
CT OF THORAX: Prior median sternotomy noted. There are bilateral pleural effusions, slightly larger on the right side. There is associated collapse with volume loss involving the posterior basal segments of both the right and left lower lobes. More confluent airspace opacity is seen radiating from the hila to involve the posterior and apical segments of the right upper lobe. The right middle lobe remains well aerated. Findings are most in keeping with pulmonary edema. Ground-glass change is also seen involving the left upper lobe again in keeping with less severe pulmonary edema. Satisfactory position of the right-sided PICC line with the tip terminating in the lower SVC. Dense calcification of the left coronary artery are seen. There are multiple nonenlarged mediastinal and axillary lymph nodes. There is a 17 x 15 mm thickening in the left subareolar region likely representing the primary tumor.
CT OF ABDOMEN: Note is made of a fundal gastric diverticulum (2:50). The liver is of diffuse increased attenuation with an average Hounsfield value of 100. Causes of this appearance include hemochromatosis, hemosiderosis, Wilson's disease and, most likely in this patients case, amiodarone drug therapy. No focal liver lesions are identified. The gallbladder outlines normally. The spleen is enlarged measuring 15 cm in long axis. Note is made of a 17-mm low- attenuation focus in the lower pole of spleen, which is incompletely characterized, but most likely represents a hemangioma. Both kidneys demonstrate cortical thinning; however, no focal lesions are identified. Both adrenal glands are normal in size and appearance. There are no pathologically enlarged upper abdominal. Abdominal aorta demonstrates sparse pleural calcifications, but is otherwise normal in characters and caliber CT OF PELVIS: The balloon of the Foley catheter lies within the prostatic portion of the urethra and should be repostioned. The prostate is normal in size and demonstrates coarse calcifications.
Normal appearance of the common femoral artery and vein with no significant perivenous hematoma following right heart catheterization. There were no enlarged inguinal or pelvic sidewall lymph nodes.
Note is made of a 21 x 18 mm low-attenuation cystic structure arising from the anterior aspect of the pancreatic body. A larger 2.8 x 3.5 cm cystic mass is seen in the pancreatic tail at the splenic hilum ( 2:56). Several other sub centimeter low attenuation foci are seen adjacent to the pancreas ( 2:56,57). Findings are in keeping with multiple pancreatic cysts or cystic neoplasms and could be further evaluated with MRCP.
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: Mild degenerative changes are seen involving the thoracolumbar spine. A 3-mm sclerotic focus in the right ilium has the appearance of a benign bone island.

TOTAL DLP: 1470.3 mGy-cm.
CT CHEST WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: A 10 x 5-mm hypodense left thyroid lobe nodule (2:1) is stable since the prior study. Mild bilateral upper lobe predominant centrilobular emphysema is seen. Few of the previously seen ground-glass nodules have resolved; however, few small sub-5-mm nodules scattered throughout both lungs persist and either remain unchanged or slightly smaller since the prior study. The nodules are seen in the right upper lobe (2:15, 18, 22), and right middle lobe, 2:22, left upper lobe (2:15, 24, 23). No new worrisome pulmonary nodule or consolidation. There has been interval resolution of previously seen bilateral small pleural effusions. The heart is normal in size. Moderate-to-severe coronary arterial calcification is present. The thoracic aorta has moderate atherosclerotic disease, without aneurysmal dilation. The pulmonary arteries are unremarkable. There is no pleural or pericardial effusion. Small scattered mediastinal lymph nodes in the pretracheal regions do not meet CT criteria for significant adenopathy. There is diffuse mild esophageal wall thickening throughout the entire thoracic portion, stable since the prior study, unclear etiology.
CT ABDOMEN WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: A 8-mm focus of arterial enhancement in the segment VII of the liver (2:54) persists, stable since the prior study, may represent a flash-filling hemangioma or FNH. No new concerning liver lesions. Few small gallstones are seen. There is no intra- or extra-hepatic biliary dilatation. The adrenal glands, spleen, and pancreas are normal. The abdominal aorta has moderate-to-severe atherosclerotic disease, with extensive calcified plaque seen in the infrarenal aorte (2:68) and both common iliac arteries. The stomach and small bowel loops are normal in appearance. The patient is status post right hemicolectomy with ileocolonic anastomosis which appears unremarkable. The adrenal glands, spleen, and pancreas are normal. Scattered small retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymph nodes do not meet CT criteria for significant adenopathy. There is no ascites.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST: The urinary bladder is almost empty. The uterus is not visualized in the study. The rectum and sigmoid colon are normal. No pelvic lymphadenopathy or free fluid is seen.
BONES AND SOFT TISSUES: No bone lesions suspicious for infection or malignancy are detected. Moderate degenerative changes are seen in the lumbar spine at L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels.

HISTORY: A 73-year-old male with history of thyroid cancer and dyspnea.
COMPARISON: MRI dated [**2121-5-15**], PET/CT [**2121-6-6**].
TECHNIQUE: Contiguous helical acquisition through the neck was performed with intravenous contrast. Coronal and sagittally reformatted images were created.
FINDINGS: There is diffuse increased soft tissue attenuation within the soft tissues of the right neck, located posterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle, encircling the right carotid artery, which is patent. The right inferior jugular vein is not visualized, likely secondary to thrombosis. There is reconstitution of the superior aspect of the internal jugular vein at the level of the superior hyoid bone, from the right branches of the external jugular vein. Also noted is a moderate sized hypodense area deep to the sternocleidomastoid, which may represent either the thrombosed internal jugular vein versus a necrotic lymph node. The abnormal area of soft tissue attenuation within the right neck extends inferiorly into the superior mediastinum surrounding the innominate artery and abutting the right aspect of the left common carotid and subclavian arteries, all of which are patent. It also extends around the trachea. No focal enhancement is noted. A stent is identified within the trachea extending from the subglottic airway to the superior mediastinum. Secretions are noted within the trachea below the level of the stent. The esophagus is patulous in appearance and appears to have a large diverticulum extending to the right of midline (2:80). Normal appearing thyroid gland is noted on the right. On the left, the superior aspect of the thyroid is identified.
There is medialization of the right vocal cord, causing narrowing of the airway at this level. Also noted is enlargement of the right ventricle, consistent with right vocal cord paralysis. The abnormal soft tissue attenuation extends to the region of the right vocal cord, and tumor invasion cannot be excluded.
The osseous structures are intact. Multilevel degenerative changes noted throughout the cervical spine with partial fusion of vertebral body C5 and C6. Well-circumscribed lytic lesions are noted within the C3, C4, vertebral bodies. seen on prior PET/CT without evidence of abnormal FDG uptake. No additional suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are identified. There is a mucus retention cyst within the left maxillary sinus. The lung apices reveal minimal emphysematous changes.

There is no abnormal air within the cervical soft tissues, and the cervical airway appears grossly intact with ET tube in place. paragraphs.context:
CLINICAL INFORMATION: The patient is an 80-year-old woman with cardiogenic shock from acute MR, with pacemaker in place. A request was made to place a temporary hemodialysis catheter with VIP port.
OPERATORS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3013**] [**Name (STitle) 3014**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 360**] [**Name (STitle) 65**], the attending radiologist, who was present and supervised during whole procedure.
PROCEDURE: Placement of temporary hemodialysis catheter.
ANESTHESIA: Lidocaine was used for local anesthesia.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: After risks and benefits of the procedure as well as local anesthesia were explained, informed consent was obtained. The patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table. The left side of the neck was prepared and draped in the usual sterile fashion. The left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle under fluoroscopic guidance. Hard copies of the ultrasound were stored. A 0.018 wire was then placed through the needle into the SVC using flouroscopic guidance. A small incision was made over the needle and the needle was removed and replaced with a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath. The wire and the inner 3 French sheath were removed and replaced with a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire with the tip of the [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire terminated in the IVC. The 4.5 French sheath was then removed over the wire and a 12 French dilator was placed over the wire to dilate the soft tissue tract into the left IJ. The dilator was then removed. A 12 French triple lumen 20-cm temporary hemodialysis catheter with a VIP port was then placed over the wire into the left IJ with the tip eventually terminated in the right atrium. All three ports of the catheter were aspirated and flushed easily. The ports were capped. The catheter was sutured to the skin and a sterile dressing was applied.
The patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no immediate complications.

answers.text: All three ports of the catheter were aspirated and flushed easily

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT CLINICAL HISTORY: This is an 83-year-old man who was in robust health until several months prior. He began a progressive, devastating, debiliting decline. Now, he suffers from multiple medical problems and pontine infarctions which have essentially left him near "locked-in". On [**1-6**], the patient underwent MRA which suggested long segmental areas of narrowing in the basilar. The patient has not tolerated long-term conservative therapy and angioplasty/stenting is considered. The patient and his family participated in a family meeting when all options were discussed extensively with the patient and family on Friday of last week and the treatment is now attempted this Monday ([**2109-2-11**]).
PROCEDURE: The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure are explained to the patient and his children. They understand and sign the consent form.
The patient is brought to the neurointerventional suite and placed under general anesthesia. A Swan-Ganz catheter is placed via left subclavian approach, radial A line is present.
The groin is prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Using standard Seldinger technique a 6 French Arrow sheath was placed in the groin. Arteriogram was performed through the dilator and demonstrates an extremely tortuous iliac and femoral system. Ultimately, a sheath exchange is performed over an exchange length 038 microwire for a 25 cm 6 French bright tip sheath. Utilizing a combination of 5 French Berenstein, 5 French [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] 2, 5 French [**Doctor Last Name 1408**] 3 in conjunction with long tapered Terumo glidewire and standard Terumo glidewire the following vessels are selected:
The 5 French Berenstein catheter is used to select the right common carotid artery. The carotid bifurcation is studied in AP and lateral projections utilizing road map technique. There is no significant stenosis. The catheter is placed in the internal carotid artery and the camera centered over the head. Arteriographic assessment in the AP and lateral planes demonstrates filling of the posterior cerebral territory, predominantly via leptomeningeal collaterals to the posterior cerebral. There is extensive intracranial atherosclerotic disease. Venous drainage is predominantly to the right side.
Next, [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1408**] 3 catheter is used to select the left common carotid artery. Examination is performed over the head via hand injection utilizing AP and lateral films. Again, seen are areas of atherosclerotic narrowing. There is a large posterior communicator with direct supply to the posterior cerebral on this left side.
Next, the 5 French Berenstein catheter is put into the base of the left vertebral artery. This is studied in the neck in AP and lateral positions. Then, the camera was centered in the brain and studied in AP and lateral positions. The left vertebral is an extremely tortuous vessel with a complete 360 degree turn in its base. The anterior spinal access is a large access arising from this artery with prominent spinal drainage seen on this examination. There is no filling of the basilar on this injection. The distal vertebral flows into the posterior inferior cerebellar. The posterior inferior cerebellar supplies anastomosis to the superior cerebellar artery.
Next, the 5 French Berenstein was placed into the right subclavian. Injection and examination of the right subclavian was done with the blood pressure cuff placed on the right arm. The right vertebral is a small vessel that appears to terminate in a small PICA. The basilar was not filled. As the caliber of the vertebral was smaller than the catheter being utilized, it was decided to not enter the vertebral.
The examination is discussed extensively with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 37273**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 15994**] of Stroke Neurology. After extensive discussion, the decision is made to stop at this point.
The long sheath is changed for a short 6 French sheath. The heparin is D/C. The sheath will be pulled with the aid of a Syvek patch in the PACU.

FINAL REPORT CT SCAN OF THE FACIAL BONES
HISTORY: Status post fall. On Coumadin. Evaluate for fracture or retrobulbar hematoma.
TECHNIQUE: Axial non-contrast imaging of the facial bones with sagittal and coronal reconstructions.
COMPARISON STUDY: CT scan of the head, dated [**2197-4-24**] reported by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1009**] as revealing numerous facial and skull fractures- see his extensive report for complete description of the findings.
FINDINGS:
The massively comminuted skull fracture is not completely depicted on this study as a number of its components lie at the vertex of the calvarium. The principal right frontal fracture appears unchanged in its configuration as does the extensively comminuted nasal bone fractures. There is an extensive fracture involving the sphenoid sinus septum, with rotation of the fracture fragment present. There is a probable additional fracture involving the basisphenoid, principally to the right of midline. The right orbital roof fracture is well depicted on the coronal images as a "blowout" type. At this time, there is no definite sign of either right orbital emphysema or pneumocephalus, aside from a tiny focus of gas near the superior portion of the falx cerebri. Nevertheless, the fact that these more extensive gas collections seen on the previous scan does raise the concern for communication between the orbit and sinuses with the intracranial region. There is a crescent-shaped of soft tissue density immediately subjacent to the right orbital roof, consistent with an orbital hematocyst. The maximum thickness of this abnormality is 6 mm. Transversely, it extends from approximately the level of the superior oblique muscle to the area of the lacrimal gland. There is no proptosis. There is a mild degree of right and more moderate left-sided periorbital soft tissue swelling noted, particularly on the medial side adjoining the nose. There is partial imaging of the petrous temporal bones, and confirmation of the suspected complex fracture of this bone on the left side, including the ossicular dislocation involving the incus. There is bilateral presumed hemotympanum and considerable opacification of the mastoid sinuses, along with marked degrees of opacification of both maxillary sinuses, likely with hemorrhagic contents. The sphenoid sinus is essentially totally opacified and there are bilateral air-fluid levels and substantial opacification of both ethmoid sinuses. Moderate mucosal thickening and a probable air-fluid level is noted within the frontal sinus. While the present study is not optimized for brain tissue detail, there is probably evidence for right frontal subarachnoid blood, but no epidural hematoma. Over the 24 hours between scans, there is development of what appear to be bilateral subdural hygromas, somewhat more prominent on the patient's left side.

FINAL REPORT HISTORY: Alcoholic with hematocrit of 15 and fluid noted on fast exam. Evaluate for intraperitoneal hemorrhage versus ascites.
No priors are available.
TECHNIQUE: MDCT-acquired axial images were obtained through the abdomen and pelvis without intravenous or oral contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformations were evaluated.
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS OR ORAL CONTRAST: Limited evaluation of lung bases displays mild atelectasis within the lingula, but is otherwise clear. There is no pleural or pericardial effusion. Marked prominence of the interventricular septum is consistent with the patient's known underlying anemia. Of note, the Hounsfield attenuation of the blood within the descending aorta is approximately 20.
The liver is enlarged with nodular contour consistent with underlying cirrhosis with no focal hepatic lesions noted on this non-contrast examination. The gallbladder is non distended and displays mild wall edema likely related to third spacing. The spleen is enlarged measuring approximately 15 cm in the coronal orientation. The pancreas, adrenal glands, and left kidney are normal. A small simple right renal cyst is noted. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are identified with scattered mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph nodes, which are likely reactive. Mild induration of the mesentery is noted. There is no free air within the abdominal cavity. A small fat-containing umbilical hernia is present.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITHOUT INTRAVENOUS OR ORAL CONTRAST: There is a mild colonic diverticulosis with no evidence of acute diverticulitis. Mild wall thickening involving the transverse and ascending colon is present.
A mild-to-moderate amount of free fluid noted within the abdomen and pelvis is in characteristic distribution for ascites. The fluid measures predominantly simple and less than the Hounsfield unit measurement of blood within the aorta. Prostate is unremarkable. No pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are present within the pelvis.
BONE WINDOWS: No malignant-appearing osseous lesions are present. There is multilevel degenerative changes noted within the lumbar spine with mild grade 1 anterolisthesis of L3 on L4. A slightly prominent Schmorl's node and/or hemangioma is also noted at the inferior aspect of the L3 vertebral body.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT (REVISED) INDICATION: Patient is status post trauma with tachycardia and question aortic injury.
TECHNIQUE: Helically acquired contiguous axial images were obtained from the thoracic inlet to the pubic symphysis after the administration of 150 cc of Optiray contrast per fast bolus protocol. Thin section and multiplanar reformations were obtained through the chest.
CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: The heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable. Specifically, the thoracic aorta is well opacified and upon review of axial and multiplanar reformation images there is no evidence of aortic tear, dissection, or transection. There is however a moderate hematoma adjacent to the aorta. There is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy. There are no pleural effusions. Bilateral chest tubes are noted, the right extending toward the posterior diaphragm and the left extending superiorly to the apex before descending along the mediastinum to the approximate level of the aortic arch. A moderate pneumothorax is noted inferiorly on the left. In addition, a small amount of air is tracking along the peripheral portion of the left chest tube. There is also subcutaneous air tracking along the thoracic cage on the left.
Dense opacification of the lungs is noted inferiorly bilaterally which is consistent with aspiration (particularly given history of difficult intubation with vomiting). In addition, there are scattered focal opacifications throughout both lungs. Of note, a focal area of opacification in the left upper lobe contains several small air filled spaces peripherally in the lung which may represent post traumatic pneumatoceles. Scout film demonstrates a Swan-Ganz catheter is well positioned with the tip in the main pulmonary trunk. An endotracheal tube is well positioned approximately 2.5 cm above the carina. A nasogastric tube is also noted and well positioned.
CT ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: The liver, spleen, gallbladder, pancreas, adrenal glands, kidneys and small bowel loops are unremarkable. There is no lymphadenopathy. A small amount of free fluid is noted throughout the abdomen which is consistent with history of peritoneal lavage. There is no free air.
CT PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: A Foley catheter is located within a somewhat distended bladder. Air within the bladder likely secondary to Foley placement. There is no lymphadenopathy. A small amount of free fluid is noted again consistent with history of peritoneal lavage. BONE WINDOWS: No evidence of fracture or other osseous abnormality.

FINAL REPORT INDICATION: 69-year-old woman with alcohol abuse, who presents with jaundice and elevated bilirubin, unclear if this represents acute on chronic alcoholic hepatitis versus other etiology of hepatitis.
RADIOLOGISTS: The procedure was performed by Drs. [**First Name (STitle) 1368**], [**Name5 (PTitle) 3014**], and [**Doctor Last Name 167**], the attending radiologist, who was present and supervising throughout.
MEDICATIONS: 1 mg of Versed and 50 micrograms of Fentanyl were administered via divided doses for moderate conscious sedation with continuous hemodynamic monitoring throught the 45 minute intraservice time ; 1 gram of Ancef was admninistered for antibiotic prophylaxis;
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: After written informed consent was obtained from the patient explaining the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure, the patient was placed supine on the angiography table, and the right neck was prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout was performed. Local anesthesia was introduced using 1% lidocaine. Using ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured. A 0.018 guide wire was advanced through the needle, and the needle was exchanged for a 4.5 French micropuncture sheath. The wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire was advanced through the micropuncture sheath into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The micropuncture sheath was then exchanged for a 9 French 45 cm [**Last Name (un) 67**] tip sheath. Using a combination of a 5 F MPA catheter and a Glidewire, access was obtained into the right hepatic vein under fluoroscopic guidance. The guide wire was exchanged for a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire, and the catheter removed, and a Cook transjugular liver core biopsy set was used to perform three passes into the right lobe of the liver, and tissue samples were obtained. The biopsy set was removed and then the catheter and vascular sheath, and manual compression was held until hemostasis was achieved. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post- procedure complications.

The largest lymph node is within the prevascular space and measures 9 mm in greatest short axis diameter. No significant hilar or axillary lymph adenopathy is identified.
Lung window images reveal bibasilar compressive atelectasis. No pulmonary nodules are identified. The airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST: The abdominal aorta is within normal limits without evidence of dissection, aneurysmal dilatation, or intramural hematoma. Mural calcifications are present within the abdominal aorta which extend into the iliacs bilaterally. The liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands, right kidney, ureters, stomach, and loops of small bowel appear unremarkable. Small hypodensities within the upper and mid pole of the left kidney are present, most simple cysts. Both kidneys enhance symetrically. The proximal ureters appear within normal limits. There is no free air or free fluid. No significant mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymph adenopathy is present. Retained contrast appears to be present in several diverticula within the descending and sigmoid colon. Otherwise, the large bowel appears unremarkable. No free fluid is identified.
BONE WINDOWS: No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are identified.
CT RECONSTRUCTIONS: Coronal and sagittal reconstructions were essential in delineating the anatomy and pathology of the aorta.

paragraphs.context:
FINAL REPORT CT OF THE HEAD WITHOUT CONTRAST DATED [**2197-4-24**].
HISTORY: 80-year-old man, status post fall, taking Coumadin; evaluate for bleed.
TECHNIQUE: Contiguous 5 mm axial tomographic sections were obtained from the skull base to the vertex and viewed in brain, bone, and lung window on the workstation.
FINDINGS: There are no comparison studies on record. There is a severe acute soft tissue injury with large right frontal and left parietovertex soft tissue swelling, subgaleal hematomas and extensive laceration with subcutaneous emphysema. This is associated with an extensive, circumferential oblique- coronal skull fracture which traverses the right frontal and left temporal bones, as well as the sphenoid bone and clivus, described in more detail below. The right frontal fracture is associated with a focal lentiform extra- axial hematoma measuring roughly 8 mm in thickness and 3.5 cm in maximal transverse dimension. This demonstrates a relatively low-attenuation portion, anteriorly, which may represent acute, non-clotted blood. This collection may be bounded by the coronal suture, and therefore lie in the epidural space. There is moderate subarachnoid hemorrhage occupying the immediately subjacent sulci, which are slightly flattened, due to the mass effect of the hematoma. No definite adjacent parenchymal contusion is seen, and there is no associated shift of the midline structures or mass effect upon the ipsilateral lateral ventricle. There is no evidence of subfalcine, uncal or downward transtentorial herniation. No significant extra-axial hematoma is identified at the corresponding left frontotemporal fracture site, though there is subarachnoid hemorrhage in the sulci in this region, and there may be a small parenchymal contusion, at the level of the left sylvian fissure.
There is extensive left supra- and periorbital soft tissue edema and hemorrhage, which does not appear to violate the orbital cone, and the retrobulbar fat in both orbits, as well as the periorbita, is preserved, though there is a small amount of right intraorbital emphysema, subjacent to an oblique fracture through that orbital roof. There is extensive acute hemorrhage within the nasal cavity and sphenoid sinus, bilaterally, with a blood-fluid level within the left maxillary antrum. Review of bone window images demonstrates extensive comminution of the vertex skull fracture, with one dominant component continuing in an oblique coronal plane and traversing the lateral wall and medial aspect of the right orbit, exiting through the ipsilateral anterior clinoid process, as well as the sphenoid sinus and the basisphenoid portion of the clivus. Note that though there is opacification of the right mastoid air cells and small fluid level within the ipsilateral middle ear cavity, no definite right temporal bone fracture is identified (on these 2.5 mm sections).
The dominant fracture component traversing the left frontal extending into the temporal bone continues as a longitudinal fracture involving the mastoid portion of the left temporal bone which, again, is largely fluid-filled with fluid in the aditus ad antrum. The relatively thick sections suggest some degree of dissociation as well as lateral displacement of the ossicular chain, related to the longitudinal fracture. Additionally, there is a suggestion of an oblique-transverse component, extending medially, which transverses the bony vestibule, with the appearance of pneumolabyrinth. Though there is extensive pneumocephalus as well as apparent dural venous gas bubbles, likely related to the series of fractures, described above, there is no definite fracture line traversing the occipital condyles, jugular foramina or hypoglossal or carotid canals, on these sections.
Also noted is extensive "smash" fracture involving the nose with extensively comminuted, overriding fractures of both nasal bones, likely involving the bony nasal septum and, probably, the maxillary spine of the nose.
COMMENT: Findings were discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 18477**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2455**] (Trauma SICU) at the immediate conclusion of the examination, and recommendation for dedicated temporal bone CT was made.

FINAL REPORT CLINICAL HISTORY: 30-year-old female, 24 weeks pregnant with TTP, requiring placement of temporary triple-lumen pheresis line with VIP port.
OPERATORS: Procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 234**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 896**] (fellow). Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 4100**] [**Name (STitle) 4101**], the attending radiologist, supervised and reviewed the study.
ANESTHESIA: 1% local lidocaine.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: After the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were explained to the patient, informed consent was obtained. The potential risks of radiation in a pregnant patient were also reviewed and confirmed with the patient. She was brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table. Her abdomen was shielded and the neck and indwelling right pheresis catheter were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A pre-procedural timeout and huddle were performed per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol. Under ultrasound guidance with hard copy images on file, a micropuncture set was used to access the left internal jugular vein and a 0.018 wire was advanced into the SVC. This was subsequently exchanged for a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**] wire. A 12 French x 16 cm pheresis catheter with VIP was selected and after sequential fascial dilatation, the catheter was placed over the wire with the tip positioned in the distal SVC. The catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk suture. The catheter was flushed and aspirated well. A final fluoroscopic spot image demonstrated good position of the catheter and no pneumothorax.
The patient was then placed on a gurney and the indwelling right pheresis catheter was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complication.

RADIOPHARMACEUTICAL DATA: 20.3 mCi F-18 FDG ([**2121-6-6**]); INDICATION: Large right thyroid mass, FNA cytology demonstrating squamous cells, with worsening dysphagia.
METHODS: Approximately 1 hour after intravenous administration of F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), noncontrast CT images were obtained for attenuation correction and for fusion with emission PET images. [The noncontrast CT images are not used to diagnose disease independently of the PET images.] A series of overlapping emission PET images was then obtained. The fasting blood glucose level, measured by glucometer before injection of FDG, was 96 mg/dL. The area imaged spanned the region from the orbits to the thighs.
Computed tomography (CT) images were co-registered and fused with emission PET images to assist with the anatomic localization of tracer uptake. The determination of the site of tracer uptake seen on PET data can have important implications regarding the significance of that uptake.
INTERPRETATION:
HEAD/NECK: A large, lobulated mass with hetergeneous solid and cystic components arises from the right thyroid lobe and extends into the superior neck at the level of the mandible. This lesion measures 7.3 cm TV x 5.2 cm AP x 8.2 cm CC, with SUVmax of 24.13. There is severe mass effect on and compression of the trachea and esophagus.
No FDG-avid intracranial lesions are seen in the imaged skull base.
CHEST: A long-segment region of circumferential wall thickening up to 1.5 cm is present in the mid-to-distal esophagus, with SUVmax of 35.12. This abnormality spans a craniocaudal distance of approximately 9.4 cm, from the level of the carina to just above the gastroesophageal junction.
An upper right paratracheal node measures 1.4 cm, with SUVmax of 17.45. 3-mm pulmonary nodule in the anterior right upper lobe is non-FDG-avid. Thoracic aortic and three-vessel coronary artery calcifications are present.
ABDOMEN/PELVIS: No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the abdomen and pelvis. Dense calcifications are present in the abdominal aorta and iliac arteries.
MUSCULOSKELETAL: No FDG-avid lesions are seen in the bones and soft tissues.
Physiologic uptake is seen in the brain, myocardium, salivary glands, GI and GU tracts, liver and spleen.

FINAL REPORT MEDICAL HISTORY: 73-year-old man with anaplastic thyroid cancer, requiring a new right-sided PICC line and removal of an existing left-sided PICC line.
CLINICIANS: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2522**] performed the procedure with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7210**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 557**], the attending radiologist, present throughout the procedure.
ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia was administered with 1% lidocaine.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: A verbal consent was obtained after explaining the procedure and risks involved to the patient. The right upper arm was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 184**] protocol.
Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set. Hard copies of ultrasound images obtained before and immediately after establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over the guide wire. There was difficulty in advancing the micropuncture wire through the right subclavian vein. A venogram was performed using 20 cc of Optiray 60%. The venogram demonstrates marked narrowing of the right subclavian vein with extensive venous collateralization. Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 0.018 guide wire was used to traverse the narrowed right subclavian vein. A 4 French PICC line measuring 40 cm was successfully positioned in the distal SVC. The position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.
The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed. The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
Under sterile technique, the existing, non-functioning left-sided PICC line was removed. A sterile dressing was again applied.

PROCEDURE: After the risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient, informed consent was obtained. The patient was brought to the angiography suite and laid in supine position. The right neck was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. A preprocedure timeout and huddle were performed. The patient's right neck was examined with ultrasound, demonstrating a patent and compressible right internal jugular vein. This vein was cannulated with a micropuncture needle just above the clavicles. Pre- and post-cannulation images were obtained and printed. A guidewire was advanced into the SVC through the needle. The needle was exchanged for a micropuncture sheath. The inner dilator and wire were removed and exchanged for [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 379**] wire, which was extended down into the upper right atrium. The sheath was exchanged for a 14 French dilator. Following dilation, the 15 cm triple lumen dialysis/pheresis catheter including VIP port was advanced over the wire with tip terminating in the high right atrium. The wire was removed, the catheter flushed. A post- procedure fluoroscopic image of the tip confirms the tip location in the high right atrium. The catheter was secured to the skin with 0-0 silk suture and dressed appropriately. There were no immediate complications.

ULTRASOUND-GUIDED CORE BIOPSY, LEFT BREAST: Preprocedure imaging again demonstrates an approximately 1.7 cm irregular hypoechoic mass in the retroareolar left breast. Targeted ultrasound of the left axilla was performed, demonstrating several normal-appearing fatty replaced lymph nodes.
Following explanation of the procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives, written informed consent was obtained with the assistance of a Russian interpreter. A preprocedure timeout was performed using three patient identifiers.
Using standard aseptic technique and 1% lidocaine for local anesthesia, under ultrasound guidance, multiple core biopsies were obtained of the hypoechoic mass in the retroareolar left breast using a 14-gauge coaxial spring-loaded biopsy device. A percutaneous clip was subsequently placed at the site of biopsy under ultrasound guidance. The needle was removed and hemostasis was achieved.
Post-procedure mammogram demonstrates accurate deployment of the percutaneous clip in the retroareolar left mass.
The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications. The patient was discharged home with standard post-biopsy instruction.
